metadata.description: Comforting Singaporean soups and stews, from clear broths to rich curries and herbal soups

recipes.name: Turtle Soup
recipes.description: Traditional herbal soup made with softshell turtle meat, Chinese herbs, and wolfberries.
steps: Blanch turtle meat, rinse well. Place in pot with chicken stock, ginger, garlic, and herbs. Simmer 2 hours.
Add wolfberries and Shaoxing wine, simmer 10 minutes more.
Season to taste, garnish with spring onions, and serve hot.
tips: Use fresh turtle for best results.
Adjust herbs to your preference.
recipes.origin: Turtle Soup is a traditional delicacy, found at a few specialty hawker stalls in Singapore.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: Chinese herbs (dang gui, yu zhu, etc.)

recipes.name: Bak Kut Teh (Pork Rib Tea Soup)
recipes.description: A classic Singaporean-Teochew soup of pork ribs simmered with garlic, white pepper, and a blend of Chinese herbs. Served with rice, youtiao (fried dough), and a chili-soy dip. Warming, peppery, and deeply comforting.

garnish/dip.youtiao (fried dough sticks): 4, toasted and cut into bite-size pieces

preparation: Blanch pork ribs in boiling water for 10 minutes. Discard water, scrape off any scum, rinse ribs well.
Toast white and black pepper in a dry pan until aromatic. Lightly crush with star anise, cloves, and cinnamon. Place spices in a filter bag.
In a large pot, bring 1.8L water to a boil. Add blanched pork ribs, salt, soy sauces, and spice bag. Simmer for 1 hour 15 minutes, lid half-covered.
Add bruised garlic and simmer another 15 minutes, or until ribs are tender. Adjust seasoning to taste.
Toast youtiao, cut into pieces. Mix sliced chili with soy sauces for dipping. Serve soup hot with rice, youtiao, and chili dip.
tips: Use fresh pork ribs with some fat for best texture.
Adjust pepper to taste for a more or less peppery soup.
You can substitute chicken for pork for a halal version (reduce cooking time).
recipes.source: Adapted from The Burning Kitchen, Nyonya Cooking, and Serious Eats
steps: Blanch pork ribs in boiling water for 10 minutes. Discard water, scrape off any scum, rinse ribs well.
Toast white and black pepper in a dry pan until aromatic. Lightly crush with star anise, cloves, and cinnamon. Place spices in a filter bag.
In a large pot, bring 1.8L water to a boil. Add blanched pork ribs, salt, soy sauces, and spice bag. Simmer for 1 hour 15 minutes, lid half-covered.
Add bruised garlic and simmer another 15 minutes, or until ribs are tender. Adjust seasoning to taste.
Toast youtiao, cut into pieces. Mix sliced chili with soy sauces for dipping. Serve soup hot with rice, youtiao, and chili dip.

recipes.name: Fish Head Curry (Singapore Style)
recipes.description: A signature Singaporean dish blending South Indian curry with Chinese-style fish head. Features snapper head, eggplant, okra, tomatoes, and a rich coconut-tamarind curry. Served bubbling hot with rice or roti.

main.lemongrass: 2 stalks, bruised and tied in a knot

preparation: Soak dried chilies in boiling water for 30 minutes, drain, chop, and blend with shallots, garlic, ginger, salt, and 2 tbsp chili soaking liquid to a coarse paste. Mix in turmeric.
Heat oil in a large saucepan over medium-high. Add mustard and fenugreek seeds, cook until mustard seeds pop.
Add spice paste, cook 6-7 minutes until oil separates. Add curry powder, curry leaves, and lemongrass, stir until fragrant.
Add 2.5 cups water, palm sugar, salt, and tamarind. Bring to a simmer. Add eggplant and fish head, cover and cook 20 minutes.
Add okra and tomatoes, cook 10 minutes more until vegetables are tender and fish is cooked through. Stir in coconut milk, heat until just simmering. Serve hot with rice or roti.
tips: Ask your fishmonger to clean and halve the fish head for you.
Use good-quality Malaysian palm sugar for authentic flavor.
You can substitute fish fillets if preferred.
recipes.source: Adapted from Serious Eats, Marion's Kitchen, and Foodelicacy
steps: Soak dried chilies in boiling water for 30 minutes, drain, chop, and blend with shallots, garlic, ginger, salt, and 2 tbsp chili soaking liquid to a coarse paste. Mix in turmeric.
Heat oil in a large saucepan over medium-high. Add mustard and fenugreek seeds, cook until mustard seeds pop.
Add spice paste, cook 6-7 minutes until oil separates. Add curry powder, curry leaves, and lemongrass, stir until fragrant.
Add 2.5 cups water, palm sugar, salt, and tamarind. Bring to a simmer. Add eggplant and fish head, cover and cook 20 minutes.
Add okra and tomatoes, cook 10 minutes more until vegetables are tender and fish is cooked through. Stir in coconut milk, heat until just simmering. Serve hot with rice or roti.

recipes.name: Soto Ayam (Singapore/Malay Chicken Noodle Soup)
recipes.description: A beloved Singaporean-Malay chicken noodle soup with a clear, aromatic broth, shredded chicken, yellow noodles or vermicelli, and a spicy-sweet sambal kicap. Served with beansprouts, fried shallots, and lime.
preparation: Blend all base paste ingredients until smooth, adding water as needed.
In a pot, heat oil and sauté star anise, cinnamon, cloves, and cardamom until fragrant. Add blended base paste and lemongrass, sauté until aromatic.
Add chicken pieces, stir to coat, then add water. Bring to a boil, then simmer for at least 30 minutes until chicken is cooked.
Remove chicken, shred meat, and set aside. Season soup with salt and white pepper.
Blanch noodles and beansprouts. Prepare sambal cili kicap by blending all ingredients until rough or smooth as desired.
To serve: Place noodles and beansprouts in a bowl, ladle soup over, top with shredded chicken, garnish with fried shallots, cilantro, and lime. Serve sambal cili kicap on the side.
tips: Use chicken thighs or a mix of parts for best flavor.
Soup can be made ahead and reheated; sambal keeps in fridge for a week.
Add potatoes, tofu, or lontong (rice cakes) for a heartier meal.
recipes.source: Adapted from Nomadette, Serious Eats, and Wikipedia.
steps: Blend all base paste ingredients until smooth, adding water as needed.
In a pot, heat oil and sauté star anise, cinnamon, cloves, and cardamom until fragrant. Add blended base paste and lemongrass, sauté until aromatic.
Add chicken pieces, stir to coat, then add water. Bring to a boil, then simmer for at least 30 minutes until chicken is cooked.
Remove chicken, shred meat, and set aside. Season soup with salt and white pepper.
Blanch noodles and beansprouts. Prepare sambal cili kicap by blending all ingredients until rough or smooth as desired.
To serve: Place noodles and beansprouts in a bowl, ladle soup over, top with shredded chicken, garnish with fried shallots, cilantro, and lime. Serve sambal cili kicap on the side.

recipes.name: Pig Stomach Soup (Bak Kut Teh Style)
recipes.description: A classic Teochew/Chinese soup featuring pig stomach simmered with white pepper, garlic, and pork ribs. Served hot with rice and youtiao.

Main.pig stomach: 1, thoroughly cleaned and cut into strips

steps: Blanch pig stomach and pork ribs in boiling water, rinse well.
In a large pot, add water, pig stomach, pork ribs, white peppercorns, garlic, and ginger. Bring to a boil, then simmer for 1.5-2 hours until tender.
Season with salt and soy sauce. Serve hot with rice and youtiao.
tips: Clean pig stomach thoroughly with salt and flour to remove odor.
Simmer gently for a clear, peppery broth.
recipes.origin: Pig Stomach Soup is a Teochew and Hokkien favorite, found at many bak kut teh and kway chap stalls.

recipes.name: Kway Chap (Braised Pig Offal with Flat Rice Noodles)
recipes.description: A Teochew hawker classic: pig offal, pork belly, and tofu braised in a savory soy-based gravy, served with flat rice noodles (kway chap).
steps: Blanch pig offal and pork belly, rinse well.
Simmer in pork bone stock with aromatics, soy sauces, and spices for 2 hours.
Add tofu and eggs in the last 30 minutes.
Serve braised offal, pork, tofu, and eggs with kway chap and some braising gravy.
tips: Clean offal thoroughly to remove odor.
Simmer gently for tender offal and rich flavor.
recipes.origin: Kway Chap is a Teochew specialty, found at many hawker centres and kopitiams.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: pig offal (intestines, stomach, fallopian tubes, etc.)

recipes.name: Bird Nest Soup
recipes.description: A luxurious Chinese delicacy: double-boiled bird's nest with rock sugar, prized for its texture and health benefits. Served at banquets and special occasions.
steps: Soak bird's nest in water until soft. Clean thoroughly.
Combine with water and rock sugar in a double boiler. Add red dates if using.
Double-boil for 1 hour until bird's nest is tender. Serve warm.
tips: Use premium bird's nest for best texture.
Adjust sweetness to taste.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore banquet kitchens.

recipes.name: Buddha Jumps Over the Wall
recipes.description: A legendary Fujianese banquet soup: abalone, sea cucumber, fish maw, dried scallops, mushrooms, and more, simmered in a rich broth. Served at special occasions in Singapore.
preparation: Blanch chicken and pork ribs. Combine all ingredients in a large pot.
Bring to a boil, then simmer 4 hours. Skim fat. Serve hot.
tips: Use premium dried seafood for best flavor.
Add more abalone or sea cucumber for luxury.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore banquet kitchens.
steps: Blanch chicken and pork ribs. Combine all ingredients in a large pot.
Bring to a boil, then simmer 4 hours. Skim fat. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Braised Sea Treasure Soup
recipes.description: A luxurious seafood soup: fish maw, dried scallops, crab meat, prawns, and mushrooms in a thick, savory broth. Served at banquets and festive occasions.
preparation: Bring stock to a boil. Add fish maw, scallops, mushrooms, crab, and prawns. Simmer 1 hour.
Thicken with cornstarch slurry. Drizzle in egg white while stirring. Season and serve.
tips: Use fresh crab for best flavor.
Add abalone for extra luxury.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore banquet kitchens.
steps: Bring stock to a boil. Add fish maw, scallops, mushrooms, crab, and prawns. Simmer 1 hour.
Thicken with cornstarch slurry. Drizzle in egg white while stirring. Season and serve.

recipes.name: Suan La Tang (Hot and Sour Soup)
recipes.description: A popular Chinese soup: spicy, tangy broth with tofu, mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and egg. Served at Chinese restaurants and home kitchens in Singapore.
preparation: Bring stock to a boil. Add pork, mushrooms, bamboo, and fungus. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add tofu, seasonings, and cornstarch slurry. Stir until thickened.
Drizzle in egg, stir to form ribbons. Finish with chili oil and spring onions.
tips: Add more vinegar for extra tang.
Use vegetarian stock for a meatless version.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Chinese restaurants.
steps: Bring stock to a boil. Add pork, mushrooms, bamboo, and fungus. Simmer 10 minutes.
Add tofu, seasonings, and cornstarch slurry. Stir until thickened.
Drizzle in egg, stir to form ribbons. Finish with chili oil and spring onions.

recipes.name: Herbal Chicken (Yao Ji)
recipes.description: A nourishing Chinese herbal soup: whole chicken braised with Chinese herbs, red dates, goji berries, and dang gui. Tonic, restorative, and deeply flavorful. Popular at home and herbal soup stalls.
preparation: Blanch chicken in boiling water, then drain.
Add all ingredients to a large pot. Bring to a boil, then simmer 2 hours.
Season with salt. Serve hot as a nourishing soup.
tips: Use a mix of Chinese herbs for best results.
Add more goji berries for sweetness.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Singapore home kitchens, and TCM recipes.
steps: Blanch chicken in boiling water, then drain.
Add all ingredients to a large pot. Bring to a boil, then simmer 2 hours.
Season with salt. Serve hot as a nourishing soup.

recipes.name: ABC Soup (Potato, Carrot, Onion Soup)
recipes.description: A nourishing, clear Chinese soup with potatoes, carrots, onions, and tomatoes, simmered with pork ribs or chicken. A family favorite for all ages.
steps: Blanch pork ribs or chicken in boiling water for 2 minutes. Drain and rinse.
In a soup pot, add water, blanched meat, potatoes, carrots, onion, tomato, corn, and honey dates.
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a gentle simmer. Cover and cook for 1 hour.
Season with salt and white pepper to taste.
Serve hot, optionally garnished with coriander.
tips: Blanching the meat helps keep the soup clear.
Add more tomatoes for a tangier soup, or honey dates for extra sweetness.
This soup is great for kids and adults alike.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: ABC Soup is a staple in Chinese households, named for its simple, 'ABC' ingredients.

recipes.name: Lotus Root Soup with Pork Ribs
recipes.description: A traditional Chinese home-style soup: pork ribs simmered with lotus root, peanuts, and red dates for a sweet, earthy, and nourishing broth.
steps: Blanch pork ribs in boiling water for 2 minutes. Drain and rinse.
In a soup pot, add water, pork ribs, lotus root, peanuts, red dates, and dried cuttlefish/scallops (if using).
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a gentle simmer. Cover and cook for 1.5–2 hours until pork and lotus root are tender.
Season with salt and white pepper to taste.
Serve hot, garnished with spring onions if desired.
tips: Blanching the ribs keeps the soup clear.
Add carrots for extra sweetness, or goji berries for color and nutrition.
Soup tastes even better the next day!
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Lotus Root Soup is a staple in Chinese households, especially for family dinners and festive occasions.

recipes.name: Winter Melon Soup
recipes.description: A light, cooling Chinese soup with winter melon, pork ribs, dried shrimp, and mushrooms. Nourishing and perfect for hot weather.

main.winter melon: 500g, peeled, seeded, and cut into cubes

steps: Blanch pork ribs in boiling water for 2 minutes. Drain and rinse.
In a soup pot, add water, pork ribs, dried shrimp, mushrooms, ginger, and bring to a boil.
Lower heat, cover, and simmer for 30 minutes.
Add winter melon cubes and goji berries (if using). Simmer another 20–30 minutes until melon is translucent and tender.
Season with salt and white pepper to taste.
Serve hot, garnished with spring onions if desired.
tips: Blanching the ribs keeps the soup clear.
Add more dried shrimp for a stronger umami flavor.
Winter melon is naturally cooling and great for hot climates.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Chinese home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Winter Melon Soup is a staple in Chinese households, especially during hot weather.
